message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest De Quervain tenosynovitis, which is caused by repetitive motions of the thumb and wrist. The pain is located in the radial styloid area and can radiate to the elbow. The other options do not fit with the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with De Quervain tenosynovitis, which is inflammation of the tendons on the thumb side of the wrist. The history of falling on the right outstretched hand may have contributed to this. The other options involve different joints and structures, and are therefore less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms include pain in the thumb and radiates to the elbow, which is consistent with De Quervain tenosynovitis. The tenderness over the radial styloid with swelling and pain indicating pathological friction between tendons and their coverings, as well as tenderness with longitudinal traction on the thumb which is the Finkelstein test, supports this diagnosis. Swan neck deformity involves hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint. Mallet finger presents with forced flexion of the distal phalanx. Carpal tunnel syndrome presents with numbness or tingling in the median nerve distribution in the hand, and the Tinel test is positive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest De Quervain tenosynovitis, which commonly occurs with repetitive wrist movements and lifting babies. The tenderness over the radial styloid, pain on longitudinal traction, and normal finger joint range of motion are consistent with this diagnosis. Swan neck deformity involves finger joint deformities, Mallet finger involves a drooping fingertip, and Carpal tunnel syndrome involves numbness and tingling in the hand.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest De Quervain tenosynovitis, which is characterized by tenderness over the radial styloid and pain with grasping and longitudinal traction. The other options don’t match the patient’s symptoms or examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the tenderness over the radial styloid with swelling but no redness, suggests the most likely diagnosis is De Quervain tenosynovitis. Swan neck deformity involves hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint, while Mallet finger involves inability to extend the distal interphalangeal joint. Carpal tunnel syndrome involves numbness and tingling in the hand, which is not described in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is De Quervain tenosynovitis. This is characterized by pain at the radial styloid with swelling and tenderness, worsened with gripping or twisting motions. There is often no involvement of other joints. Swan neck deformity is a finger deformity, Mallet finger is caused by a tendon injury, and Carpal tunnel syndrome involves numbness or tingling in the hand.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest De Quervain tenosynovitis, which is caused by inflammation of the tendons and sheath of the first dorsal compartment of the wrist. The location of the tenderness over the radial styloid and the positive Finkelstein test (grasping the thumb and exerting longitudinal traction) support this diagnosis. The other options do not fit with the patient’s symptoms and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of pain in the thumb and wrist radiating to the elbow, tenderness over the radial styloid, and pain on longitudinal traction suggest the diagnosis of De Quervain tenosynovitis. Swan neck deformity involves a deformity of the finger, while Mallet finger is a deformity of the finger caused by a tendon injury. Carpal tunnel syndrome would involve symptoms in multiple fingers, not just the thumb.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest De Quervain tenosynovitis, which is inflammation of the tendons and tendon sheaths on the thumb side of the wrist. This is often caused by repetitive motions involving gripping or pinching, which is consistent with the patient holding her infant son. The tenderness over the radial styloid and pain elicited by longitudinal traction towards the ulnar side are classic signs of De Quervain tenosynovitis. The other options are unlikely given the location of symptoms and lack of other joint involvement.
